title: 104_s1206
content: The "Adoption Assistance Act" is also known as the Adoption Assistance Act. It introduces a refundable credit for adoption expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Adoption Assistance Act allows for a tax credit for qualified adoption expenses paid by an individual, with a limit of $5,000. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's income, with no double benefits allowed. The tax credit for qualified adoption expenses is based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeding $60,000, with a limit of $40,000. No double benefits are allowed, and the credit is not applicable if funds are received from other programs. Qualified adoption expenses include fees directly related to the legal adoption of a child. The definition of 'qualified adoption expenses' includes reasonable and necessary fees directly related to the legal adoption of a child. Expenses for adopting a spouse's child are not eligible. Married couples must file joint returns for this tax credit. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. The tax credit for qualified adoption expenses requires married couples to file joint returns. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. Title II of the document focuses on adoption assistance for federal employees, specifically reimbursement for adoption expenses. The effective date for the amendments mentioned in this section is for taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. Title II of the document discusses adoption benefits for federal employees, including reimbursement for adoption expenses such as fees charged by adoption agencies, legal fees, and medical expenses. The definition of terms like 'agency' and 'employee' are also provided in this section. The regulations establish a program for federal employees to be reimbursed for adoption expenses, including fees charged by adoption agencies, legal fees, medical expenses, foster-care charges, and transportation expenses. Reimbursement is provided after the adoption becomes final, the child is under 18 years of age and unmarried. Under the regulations, reimbursement for adoption expenses is provided after the adoption becomes final, the child is under 18 years of age and unmarried, and a written application is filed. Reimbursement is only payable if other benefits do not cover the full expenses and is capped at $2,000 per child for eligible employees. If both adopting parents are eligible, each parent can receive reimbursement. The reimbursement for adoption expenses is capped at $2,000 per child for eligible employees. If both adopting parents are eligible, each parent can receive reimbursement. No amount shall be payable if it would cause the total amount to exceed the lesser of the total adoption expenses or $4,000. Amounts payable under this section are paid from the appropriation or fund used to pay the employee involved. The guidelines for adoption expense reimbursement include provisions for interagency cooperation and other measures. Reimbursement amounts are paid from the appropriate fund. Applications cannot be denied based on marital status. The Office of Personnel Management may issue general guidelines for uniform administration. Executive agencies must follow these guidelines. The Office can provide assistance upon request. Title III of the document excludes adoption assistance and specifies the effective date as October 1, 1995. The section also outlines the applicability of certain regulations to Postal Service employees. Title III of the document excludes adoption assistance, effective October 1, 1995, and applies to finalized adoptions after that date. It amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section on adoption assistance. The document excludes adoption assistance from an employee's gross income, including employee and military adoption assistance benefits. Definitions for employee adoption assistance benefits, employer, employee, and military adoption assistance benefits are provided. Qualified adoption expenses are also defined. The term 'military adoption assistance benefits' refers to benefits provided under specific sections of the United States Code. 'Qualified adoption expenses' include necessary fees and costs directly related to legal adoption of an eligible child, without violating any laws. An 'eligible child' is defined as an individual under 18 at the time of adoption. The Secretary will issue regulations to coordinate the application of this section with other provisions allowing a credit or deduction for qualified adoption expenses. A clerical amendment updates the table of sections in the Code. Effective Date: The amendments made in this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
